section.title: Present perfect and Past simple with for
section.sectiontitle: We use the Present perfect with for to talk about state or actions which continue from the past to the present.
section.text1: I went to New York two weeks ago. I'm still in New York now.
section.text1a: I've been in New York for two weeks.
section.text2: I got married three years ago. I'm still married now.
section.sectiontitle2: We use the Past simple with for to talk about a past state or actions in a period of time which is finished.
section.text3: I went to New York in 2002 but now I'm home.
section.text3a: I was in New York for two weeks in 2002.
section.text4: I got married in 2000. I got divorced in 2003.

section.title: Present perfect
section.sectiontitle: In the positive, we use I/you/we/they have and he/she/it has + past participle.
section.text1a: We've known each other for a long time.
section.sectiontitle2: Regular past participles end in -ed or -ied. There are also many irregular past participles.

section.title: Present perfect
section.sectiontitle: In the negative, we use I/you/we/they haven't and he/she/it hasn't + past participle.
section.text1a: I haven't seen Pat for a long time.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we use have I/you/we/they and has he/she/it + past participle.
section.text3a: Have you driven far? Yes, I have.
